description: From Old English stot, stotte (‚Äúa hack, jade, or worthless horse‚Äù), in turn from Old Norse st√∫tr. Compare Swedish stut (‚Äúa bull‚Äù), Danish stud (‚Äúan ox‚Äù). Compare stoat.

Likely derived from Middle Dutch stoten (‚Äúto push‚Äù) or Middle Low German st√¥ten, from Old Saxon st≈çtan, from Proto-West Germanic *stautan, from Proto-Germanic *stautanƒÖ (‚Äúto push, jolt, bump‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)tewd-, from *(s)tew- (‚Äúto push, hit‚Äù).
Also compare Middle English steten (‚Äúto thrust, strike, push, knock down‚Äù), Old Norse stauta and steyta (whence Danish st√∏de), Gothic êçÉêçÑêå∞êåøêçÑêå∞êåΩ (stautan), Old Saxon stotan.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Northern England) A bounce or rebound
examples: Instead of dropping the golden cones safely into his bag he let them dribble out of his hands so that, in the expectancy before the violence of the storm, the tiny stots from one transfigured branch to another could be clearly heard.

entries.meaning: (zoology, of quadrupeds) A leap using all four legs at once.

verbs.description: stot (third-person singular simple present stots, present participle stotting or stottin, simple past and past participle stotted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Scotland and Northern England) To bounce, rebound or ricochet.
examples: ‚ÄòI've plenty of money in my bank ‚Äì and I have my cheque book here ‚Äì could one of you cash a cheque for five pounds? ‚Äì I promise it won't stot.‚Äô

entries.meaning: (transitive, Scotland and Northern England) To make bounce, rebound or ricochet.
(transitive, Scotland and Northern England) To stumble.
(intransitive, zoology, of quadrupeds) To leap using all four legs at once.
